nodes.text: Machine learning can provide novel insights, more accurate analysis of accident and degradation datasets, and enable better decision-making to improve reliability engineering and safety applications
Machine learning comprises supervised, unsupervised, semi-supervised, and reinforcement learning categories, each with characteristic tasks and models

Supervised learning (regression and classification) has been successfully applied to remaining useful life (RUL) estimation, degradation prediction, and fault classification using SVR, GPR, decision trees, random forests, and deep neural networks

Unsupervised learning (clustering and anomaly detection) is useful for pattern discovery and early fault/anomaly detection in streaming sensor and time-series data, with methods including K-means, SOM, density-based clustering, and deep autoencoders

Semi-supervised learning leverages abundant unlabeled data with scarce labels to improve prognostics and fault detection performance using graph-based methods, ladder networks, variational autoencoders, and co-training

Reinforcement learning, including deep and safe RL, can address large-scale inspection and maintenance planning and sequential decision problems that are intractable for conventional MDP/POMDP approaches

Deep learning (DL) offers distinctive advantages for high-dimensional, nonlinear, temporal, and image-based reliability and safety tasks (e.g., CNNs, RNNs/LSTMs, autoencoders, GANs, deep Gaussian processes)
ML model construction relies on datasets, objective/loss functions, and optimization algorithms; choice of model and evaluation/benchmarking is critical due to No Free Lunch theorems

Evidence from reviewed studies shows ML regression models (SVR, GPR, DNN, LSTM) achieved improved RUL and degradation prediction accuracy across domains (batteries, bearings, turbines, aircraft engines)

Evidence from reviewed studies shows ML classifiers, clustering, anomaly detection, and SSL methods produced accurate fault detection, anomaly detection, and health-state classification across domains including wind turbines, spacecraft telemetry, gas turbines, and industrial machinery

Spacecraft telemetry anomaly detection demonstrates both opportunity and challenge: deep models (LSTM, autoencoders, OC-SVM) can find contextual anomalies but face high false positive rates that limit operational adoption

Future priority opportunity: quantify and reduce uncertainty and incorporate deployment considerations (confidence intervals, sources of uncertainty) to lower false alarms and increase operational trust

Additional near-term opportunities: (a) ML for fleet-level and system-of-systems PHM and transfer learning, (b) integration of ML with accident databases and safety management systems to mine near-miss and heterogeneous data, (c) integration of ML with wearable sensors for predictive safety analytics and injury prevention, and (d) leveraging advanced models such as deep Gaussian processes and GANs for better uncertainty handling and high-dimensional generative modeling

Conclusion: The literature is large but fragmented; ML has demonstrable value in reliability and safety and should be integrated into traditional toolkits while addressing uncertainty, deployment, interpretability, and operational adoption challenges

Limitation and research needs: operational adoption is hindered by high false positive rates, publication bias (especially in SSL), computational cost of deep models, interpretability challenges, and the need for risk analysis of ML/AI systems themselves
